title: Line Of Duty season 6 could air ‘sometime in 2020’
text:
We might get another series of Line Of Duty next year (Picture: World Productions/Aiden Monaghan)

Line of Duty could return in 2020, according to the show’s creator.

Series creator and writer Jed Mercurio has revealed he hopes series six will be aired ‘sometime in 2020’, but he admitted there is no official announcement just yet.

Speaking to RadioTimes.com, Jed said: ‘I would hope its sometime in 2020, next year. But that’s not something we’re able to confirm.’

The season five finale aired back in May after a two-year gap between series and since then fans have been eager to find out exactly when season six will be hitting our screens.

But if we are set to get a new series in 2020, it may be later in the year as opposed to earlier, as Jed admitted that the production is still at the ‘planning stage’.

He said: ‘That’s something that we have at the planning stage, so we are working towards a date. We can’t confirm everything until things are in place.’

Vicky McClure stars as Kate Fleming in Line Of Duty (Picture: BBC)

The series follows AC-12’s Superintendent Ted Hastings (Adrian Dunbar), DI Kate Fleming (Vicky McClure) and DS Steve Arnott (Martin Compston) as they investigate corrupt police officers.

There’s not too much info yet on exactly what to expect from the next series of the show, but Jed did drop a pretty huge potential clue on Twitter earlier this year as he hinted that series six would feature a crossover of the first and second series.

Re-posting a photo of Lenny James and Keely Hawes, who played Tony Gates and Lindsay Denton on the show, he commented: ‘Looking forward to seeing you meet in Series 6.’

Jed is currently discussing the future of his other hit show Bodyguard (Picture: BBC)

But bringing them back might be tricky as both characters – spoiler alert – have been killed off.

Jed – who also created Bodyguard for the BBC – revealed earlier this year that he was in talks with the broadcaster about the future of both his shows.

He previously said: ‘We’re currently in talks with the BBC about the future of both series. So at this point it’s not possible to say what will happen next.

‘But it’s impossible to work on the two of them simultaneously, so it would have to be sequential.’

He has made it clear he would love Line of Duty to return for a seventh series after a sixth was already commissioned.
